subject: RE: [junit] How to add functionality for execution flexibilty?
msgSnippet: Michael, You re right that the JUnit documentation needs to be improved. As a volunteer project, we re open to contributions. The following example may serve
messageBody:
Michael,

You're right that the JUnit documentation needs to be improved. As a
volunteer project, we're open to contributions.

The following example may serve to address the situation you raise:

public class FilterExample {
@Test public void runTestsInAList() {
final String[] tests= new String[] {"a", "b"};
Filter namedTests= new Filter() {
@Override
public String describe() {
return "only tests starting with 'a'";
}
@Override
public boolean shouldRun(Description description) {
for (String each : tests)
if
(description.getDisplayName().startsWith(each))
return true;
return false;
}
};
Request request=
Request.aClass(Tests.class).filterWith(namedTests);
Result result= new JUnitCore().run(request);
assertEquals(2, result.getRunCount());
}
public static class Tests {
@Test public void a() {}
@Test public void b() {}
@Test public void c() {}
}
}

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

Subject: [junit] How to add functionality for execution flexibilty?



I am looking to add the following functionality to my tests:
- When provided a list of method names on the command line, only
those
methods in the invoked class will be executed.

I need this implementation at the test class level. This was pretty
straightforward with JUnit 3.8.1 - just create new instances of the
derived TestCase with the method name as the argument, and add them
to
the suite.

I am having a lot of difficulty trying to replicate this
functionality. The filter logic appears to be a one-shot exclusion
filter (everything not matching is dropped), and I can't seem to
find
any documentation that would address this.

As Mr. Rainsberger and others have suggested, I have searched the
web
for an appropriate tutorial. I have found a number of good basic
tutorials (including some references in this group), and a couple
with
some advanced content. I cannot seem to find one with the detail to
unlock the tools and capabilities that I am positive are available
within the new JUnit framework.

I am also convinced that no one is as capable as the authors in
documenting the features of the framework, and I am having trouble
find Javadoc for some of the classes and APIs in the JUnit 4.1 tree.
There is a fairly good chance that I am looking in the wrong place.

If anyone has any suggestions or guidance on these issues, it would
be
greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance!

Michael Schechter
